DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Call Oliver North's Appeal Arguments Unsound
DOC.TEXT: The government protected its case against Oliver L. North from the possible taint of his immunized testimony, Iran-Contra prosecutors assert in opposing North's bid to get his convictions reversed. In a 70-page federal appeals court brief Friday, prosecutors characterized as ``legally and factually unsound'' North's argument that the government won three felony convictions against him without properly guarding against all use of immunized testimony he gave on Capitol Hill. ``The extraordinary protective procedures undertaken'' by prosecutors and the court ``assured that North's immunized testimony did not contribute to his conviction,'' said associate independent counsel Gerald Lynch. Prosecutors in the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh were instructed to avoid learning the ontents of immunized testimony from any source in the Iran-Contra affair. U.S. District Judge Gerhard Gesell, who presided at North's trial, ``undertook extraordinary efforts to protect North's rights,'' Lynch said. North told the appeals court last month he was convicted with ``a stunning disregard'' for his 5th Amendment rights against self-incrimination. ``North does not contend ... that any of the government's trial witnesses were discovered as a result of his congressional testimony, or that a single specific piece of grand jury or trial evidence was derived from that testimony,'' responded the prosecution. Walsh's office said North ``objects only to the trial court's alleged failure `to follow the procedures established to protect core Fifth Amendment rights.''' North's appeal is scheduled for argument Feb. 6. The prosecution also said Gesell made the correct decision in quashing North's subpoena seeking to compel former President Reagan to testify at his trial. North said his activities were authorized by the president and is raising Reagan's absence at the trial as an issue on appeal. ``North could not identify a single instance where President Reagan directly told him to formulate a false chronology or to commit other obstructions,'' said the court filing. ``North's almost total lack of direct contact with the president is apparent'' from evidence collected by Walsh's office and from North's own testimony at his trial, said the prosecution.
